docs.summary: The wix-site module contains functionality for obtaining information about your site and its pages.
description: To use the site module, import `wixSite` from the `wix-site` module:
```javascript
import wixSite from 'wix-site';
The APIs in `wix-site` can only be used in front-end code.

docs.summary: Gets a code representing the site's currency.
description: The retrieved currency code corresponds to the currency that has been
entered in the General Info section of your site's Dashboard.
The currency is used your site, apps (e.g. Wix Stores, Wix Bookings), and other
Wix features.

docs.summary: Gets information about the current page or lightbox.

examples.title: Get information about the current page
Get information about the current lightbox

docs.summary: Gets a code representing the site's language.
description: The retrieved language code corresponds to the main site language
as found in the General Info section of your site's Dashboard.
> **Note:** If you have a multilingual site, and it is being viewed in a language
that is not the main site language, the `language` property still returns
the main site language. To work with the languages of a multilingual site,
use the [Multilingual API](wix-window.multilingual.html).
The retrieved regional settings corresponds to the regional settings
that has been entered in the General Info section of your site's Dashboard.
The regional settings are used to determine how numbers, dates, and currencies
are displayed on your site.
The site revision ID is a unique identifier for the current revision of
your site. Each time you manually save your site or publish your site
following a change, a new revision is created.
You can view and manage your site revisions in your [Site History](https://support.wix.com/en/article/viewing-and-managing-your-site-history).
You can use [site monitoring](https://support.wix.com/en/article/about-site-monitoring#site-revisions) to
monitor and debug new revisions of your site.
> **Notes:**
> + Since publishing your site may change the revision ID, the ID when
>   previewing your site may be different than the ID for the published site.
> + The site revision ID is guaranteed to be unique, but not meaningful.
>   Therefore, you cannot predict future revision IDs before they are created.
The retrieved timezone is the timezone that has been
entered in the General Info section of your site's Dashboard.
The timezone is used your site, apps (e.g. Wix Stores, Wix Bookings), and other
Wix features.
Retrieves the site display name, which is the name that
has been entered in the **Website Settings** section of the site's [**Dashboard**](https://support.wix.com/en/article/wix-dashboard-overview).

ret.doc: An object that contains information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes.

docs.summary: Returns information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes.
description: The returned `SiteStructure` object is a flattened representation of the site.
The structure does not include the headers and links from the site's **Pages** menu.

examples.title: Get information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes

extra.description:
This example gets the structure of the site with the following in its pages menu:
 ![Site Structure](images/site_structure.png "Site Structure")

params.name: prefetchItems
params.doc: The items within the site to prefetch resources for.

docs.summary: Optimizes resource fetching of pages and lightboxes in the site so they will load faster.
description: Use the `prefetchPageResources()` function to optimize resource fetching of pages and
lightboxes you think your site visitors are likely to visit next. When the site
visitor navigates to those pages or lightboxes, they will load quicker than usual
since some of their resources have already been retrieved.
You can only prefetch resources from pages or lightboxes within the current site.
A prefetch is considered successful if the specified pages and lightboxes exist in
the current site. If any of the specified pages or lightboxes do not exist, the
prefetch operation returns an error status and lists of the pages and lightboxes
that were not found.

params.name: routerPrefix
params.doc: The prefix of the router to get the sitemap for.

ret.doc:
Fulfilled - A list of sitemap entries.
Rejected - The error that caused the rejection.

docs.summary: Returns the sitemap for a router or dynamic page prefix.
description: The `routerSitemap()` function returns a Promise that resolves to a list of
[`WixSitemapEntry`](wix-router.WixRouterSitemapEntry.html) objects. Each
[`WixSitemapEntry`](wix-router.WixRouterSitemapEntry.html) includes
information about a page, such as its URL, title, and name.
A sitemap is used by search engines to find the links to the site's pages.

examples.title: Get the sitemap for a prefix

docs.summary:
An object that contains information about which pages and lightboxes to
 prefetch resources for.

members.name: pages
members.doc:
The relative or absolute URLs of the pages in your site
 to prefetch resources for.

members.name: lightboxes
members.doc:
The names of the lightboxes in your site to prefetch 
 resources for.

 > **Note:** Pages are listed by relative or absolute URL, but lightboxes are listed by name. 
 See [`wix-location.to()`](wix-location.html#to) to learn how to find a page's relative 
 URL. You can find a lightbox's name by selecting the lightbox and clicking the settings button.

docs.summary: An object that is returned from a prefetch request.

members.name: message
members.doc: A success or failure message.

members.name: errors
members.doc: The errors that occurred.

docs.summary: An object that is returned when a resource prefetch is unsuccessful.

members.name: pages
members.doc: The names of the pages for which prefetch failed.

members.name: lightboxes
members.doc: The names of the lightbox for which prefetch failed.

docs.summary: An object that contains information about the site's prefixes.

examples.title: Get information about the site's prefixes

extra.description:
This example gets the prefixes of the site with the following in its pages menu:
 ![Site Structure](images/site_structure.png "Site Structure")

members.name: name
members.doc: The name of the prefix.

members.name: type
members.doc:
The type of the prefix.
 
 A site's routers, dynamic pages, and app pages all have prefixes.

 One of: 

 + `"dynamicPages"`
 + `"router"`
 + `"app"`

members.name: prefix
members.doc: The prefix.

members.name: applicationId
members.doc: If the prefix is an app's prefix, the `applicationId` property is the app's ID.

docs.summary: An object that contains information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes.

examples.title: Get information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes

extra.description:
This example gets the structure of the site with the following in its pages menu:
 ![Site Structure](images/site_structure.png "Site Structure")

members.name: pages
members.doc:
The pages of the site.
 Pages can be regular pages, dynamic pages, router pages, or pages from an app.

members.name: prefixes
members.doc: The prefixes of the site's routers and dynamic pages.

members.name: lightboxes
members.doc: The site's lightboxes.

docs.summary: An object that contains information about a lightbox on the site.

examples.title: Get information about the current lightbox
Get information about the site's lightboxes

extra.description:
This example gets the lightboxes of the site with the following in its pages menu:
 ![Site Structure](images/site_structure.png "Site Structure")

members.name: name
members.doc: The name of the lightbox.

docs.summary: An object that contains information about a page on the site.

examples.title: Get information about the current page
Get information about the site's pages

extra.description:
This example gets the pages of the site with the following in its pages menu:
 ![Site Structure](images/site_structure.png "Site Structure")

members.name: name
members.doc: The name of the page.

members.name: type
members.doc: The type of the page: `"static"` or `"template"`.

members.name: url
members.doc: The URL of the page. If the page is a `static` page the `url` property is the page's SEO URL.

members.name: applicationId
members.doc: If the page is an app page, the `applicationId` property is the app's ID.

members.name: prefix
members.doc: If the page is a router or dynamic page, the `prefix` property is the page's prefix.

members.name: isHomePage
members.doc: If the page is the Home page, `isHomePage` is `true`. Otherwise, it does not exist.

FAQs.title: How are dynamic pages listed in the site structure?
FAQs.markdown: When you call the [`getSiteStructure()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-site.html#getSiteStructure) function, you receive an object that contains information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes. Dynamic pages are included in this object in the `pages` property, along with all the other pages in your site. The objects in the `pages` array that correspond to dynamic pages contain a `name` property like all other pages, a `type` property with the value `template`, and a `prefix` property with the dynamic page's prefix.

FAQs.title: Does the site structure include nested pages?
FAQs.markdown: Yes. When you call the [`getSiteStructure()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-site.html#getSiteStructure) function, you receive an object that contains information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes. Nested pages are included in this object in the `pages` property, along with all the other pages in your site.

FAQs.title: Does site structure return lightboxes?
FAQs.markdown: Yes. When you call the [`getSiteStructure()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-site.html#getSiteStructure) function, you receive an object that contains information about the site's pages, prefixes, and lightboxes. Lightboxes are included in this object in the `lightboxes` property.

FAQs.title: What's the difference between the 'fetch()' and 'getJSON()' functions?
FAQs.markdown: The [`fetch()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html#fetch) function performs a fetch which returns a general-purpose result which can contain different response types. It also contains information about the response. The [`getJSON()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html#getJSON) function just returns a JSON response without any additional information. Use [`getJSON()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html#getJSON) when all you need is the JSON response. Use [`fetch()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html#fetch) in all other situations.

FAQs.title: How do I make a CORS request?
FAQs.markdown: Certain [CORS](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS) (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) requests are restricted when originating from a browser. Usually, GET requests and certain POST requests can be made from your site's **Public**, **Page**, or **Site** code. All other requests need to be made from your site's **Backend** code. If you are experiencing an issue with a [`fetch()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html) call due to a CORS restriction, move the [`fetch()`](https://www.wix.com/code/reference/wix-fetch.html) call to the backend as described in [Accessing 3rd Party Services](https://support.wix.com/en/article/accessing-3rd-party-services#backend-service-call).

FAQs.title: Can I fetch resources that start with http and not https?
FAQs.markdown: You cannot request HTTP content if your site is an HTTPS site. To fix this issue you can either use the HTTPS protocol to fetch the requested resources or you can [turn off SSL on your site](https://support.wix.com/en/article/enabling-https-for-your-wix-site).
